titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Joseph Desloge river running video collection 1942-1958
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Tawnya Mosier and Roy Webb.

publicationstmt.publisher: Multimedia Archives, J. Willard Marriott Library, University of Utah

repository.corpname: University of Utah Libraries, Special Collections

did.unittitle: Joseph Desloge river running video collection
did.abstract: The Joseph Desloge river running video collection (1942-1958) consists almost entirely of footage of river trips on the Green and Colorado Rivers. Several films were shot at the Grand Canyon. The collection also contains movies of trips on other rivers and of the Desloge family's other vacations and home life. Joseph Desloge was a St. Louis industrialist and philanthropist who frequently vacationed on the rivers of the West and joined expeditions led by prominent river guides of the mid 20th century.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Joseph "Joe" Desloge (1889-1971) was born in St. Louis, Missouri to Lydia Davis and Firmin Vincent Desloge, who had moved to St. Louis to attend St. Louis University. A descendant of French immigrants, Joseph Desloge served in the French army in WWI and was decorated for bravery near Vouziers. He graduated from the Massachusettes Institute of Technology (MIT) in 1912 with a degree in electrical engineering and founded the Minerva Oil Company (miners of zinc and fluorspar), Killark Electric Manufacturing Company, Louisiana Manufacturing Company and Atlas Manufacturing Company. In 1946, built an elegant mansion in Florissant, Missouri, whcih he named "Vouziers" after the site of his glory in France. A frequent vacationer on the Colorado River, Desloge used his wealth to preserve and share natural landscapes in his home state by donating the land to create Johnson's Shut-Ins State Park in Reynold County, Missouri and Sunset Park in the city of Florissant. Desloge and his first wife, Anne Kennett Farrar, had four children. She died in 1934, and Desloge spent his later years with Anna Margaret Saalfrank, whom he married in 1953. Joseph Desloge passed away in 1971.

scopecontent.p: The Joseph Desloge river running video collection (1942-1958) consists almost entirely of original and composite print films and videocassettes of river trips on the Green and Colorado Rivers. Several films were shot at the Grand Canyon. The collection also contains movies of trips on other rivers and of the Desloge family's other vacations and home life.

arrangement.p: The materials are arranged chronologically by format type.

accessrestrict.p: Materials must be used on-site; no use of original material, access copies will be made available for viewing. Five business days advanced notice required. Access to parts of this collection may be restricted under provisions of state or federal law, condition of the material, or by donor.

relatedmaterial.p: For photographs of some of these river trips see Northern Arizona University's Bill Belknap collection.

processinfo.p: Processed by Tawnya Mosier and Roy Webb in 2001.

scopecontent.p: This copy does not contain parts excerpted for composite print on 09/20/1954.
Wind River Mountains river trip with Erma and Christy (1954)
Joe Desloge, A.H., M.D. and Zoe Desloge.
Joe Desloge, Marie Saalfrank and A.K. Reynolds.
With Hugh Cutler, Otis "Dock" Marston and others.
Composite print including boat upset, Otis "Dock" Marston, etc.

did.unittitle: Colorado River, Green River, San Juan River
Green River, Colorado River, San Juan River

scopecontent.p: Four separate river trips are included on this film reel. Participants include Norman Nevills, Otis "Dock Marston," H.K., Loc Moore, Arthur, (M)Hilotte, Comptons.
Boat trip, Statue of Liberty, New York City skyline, etc.
With Norman Nevills, Anne Desloge, B.D., Zoe Desloge, Marie Saalfrank, Comptons, Arthur, Botty and John.

arrangement.p: These videos are arranged in the order in which they appear on the videocassettes, with 1.1 being the first film on the first cassette, 1.2 being the second film on the first cassette and so on.

scopecontent.p: These cassettes contain footage of river trips and occasional other home movies dubbed from 16mm or 8mm film. Scenes were filmed in the Grand Canyon unless otherwise noted.

did.unittitle: Otis Marston presents: Through the Grand Canyon by boat.

scopecontent.p: Maps of river and Grand Canyon
Norman Nevills demonstrating "face your danger" river running technique with model, diagram
Launch, with powerboat in background (unidentified boat)

Phanton Ranch, swimming in pool, loading boats at Bright Angel Creek
Running rapids in Middle Granite Gorge
End of trip, tow-out on Lake Mead

Hiking, rock-hounding in badlands along river

Various inscriptions: Kolb brothers, Clyde Eddy, Pathe-Bray, Hydes

Aerial tram car at Bass Camp, Grand Canyon

Rapids: scouting, running, with helicopter overhead
Film of boat running rapids, taken from helicopter.

"Danger River" consists of outtakes from Olsen's 1946 Academy Award winning short, "Facing Your Danger." Both films were compiled from footage filmed during a 1942 Grand Canyon river trip with Nevills Expeditions.
View from South Rim, Grand Canyon
Nevills working on boats, loading boats, boats on trailer approaching Lees Ferry, launching boats, packing boats
Flip at Tanner Rapid, 1942; Ed Hudson in water holding onto boat
Numerous scenes of running various rapids
233 mile rapid (narrator's identification of location may be incorrect)
Last shot of wave in rapid
